content:
What a wonderful idea! Yes, it's absolutely possible to include your grandmother's birth and death dates, as well as her relationship to you, on the garden stone or plaque. This will make the memorial even more personal and meaningful.

Here are a few examples of how you could phrase the inscription:

* "In loving memory of Grandma [Grandma's Name], born [Birth Date], passed away [Death Date]. Beloved grandmother on my mother's side."
* "Dedicated to the memory of Grandma [Grandma's Name], [Birth Date] - [Death Date]. A loving grandmother, cherished by all."
* "Grandma [Grandma's Name], mother's mother, [Birth Date] - [Death Date]. Her love of gardening lives on in our hearts."
* "In remembrance of Grandma [Grandma's Name], born [Birth Date], passed away [Death Date]. A garden of love, nurtured by her gentle hands."

You can choose a phrase that resonates with you, or feel free to modify these examples to fit your needs. Make sure to check with the manufacturer or engraver to ensure they can accommodate the length and style of the inscription you prefer.

When selecting a garden stone or plaque, consider the following:

* Material: Choose a durable material that can withstand outdoor weather conditions, such as stone, ceramic, or metal.
* Size: Select a size that fits comfortably in the designated area, and ensure it's large enough to accommodate the inscription.
* Design: Opt for a design that complements the surrounding garden or area. You can choose a simple, elegant design or something more decorative, depending on your grandmother's style.
* Color: Select a color that blends with the surroundings or one that was meaningful to your grandmother.

Remember to proofread the inscription carefully before finalizing the order to ensure everything is accurate and to your liking.

I hope this helps! If you have any more questions or need further guidance, feel free to ask.
